https://doi.org/10.5066/P9FG9DEO"]},"pointOfContact":[{"party":[{"contactId":"1b759b80-bb2a-4b66-898d-56e4c9b4a341"}],"role":"pointOfContact"}],"abstract":"This dataset provides information on the identity and number of insects that emerged from thaw pond basins on the central Arctic Coastal Plain, Alaska, during the summer growing season in 2012 and 2013. Collections were made using passive floating emergence traps in pond centers and margins from four types of ponds: low centered polygons, troughs, small coalescent, and large coalescent. A single table provides detail on the family level identity and number of insects captured, the day and year of capture, and the duration of trapping.","status":["completed"],"defaultResourceLocale":{"language":"eng","characterSet":"UTF-8","country":"USA"},"timePeriod":{"startDateTime":"2012-06-30T08:00:00.000Z","endDateTime":"2013-06-25T08:00:00.000Z","description":"ground condition"},"extent":[{"geographicExtent":[{"description":"The study was focused on a 9 km by 9 km plot in the Chipp River Basin in the central arctic coastal plain, Alaska, USA. Any organisms that could not be identified to family (3% of individuals) and any captured larva (non-emergent) were removed from the analysis. We determined the number and identities of families observed in each pond class. In each sample, counts of insect families were standardized for area and the number of days the trap was deployed."},{"timePeriod":{"endDateTime":"2013-01-01T09:00:00.000Z"},"stepId":"3","scope":{"scopeCode":"attribute"},"description":"Summary statistics were examined across the pond classes and mean density was determined by taxonomic family and origin (i.e., aquatic, semiaquatic, and terrestrial). Origin was determined from literature (Borror et al. 1989; Merrit et al. 2008)."},{"timePeriod":{"endDateTime":"2013-01-01T09:00:00.000Z"},"stepId":"1","scope":{"scopeCode":"fieldSession"},"description":"The collected petri dishes from emergence traps were placed on a marked grid (2 x 2 cm) and the insects in each cell were identified (to family level, where possible) and counted under a dissecting microscope. Body length (excluding antennae) was measured to the nearest millimeter. When a complete census of trapped adults was not feasible due to high abundance (> 500 individuals), a subset of cells (n = 13) was counted"}],"source":[{"sourceId":"2722d971-c3bc-425d-9b0a-e92cb7f6323d","sourceCitation":{"responsibleParty":[{"party":[{"contactId":"999dc9b9-b3a4-4b5a-918e-114185f8be1b"}],"role":"publisher"},{"party":[{"contactId":"debd71d3-3925-4b04-bb8c-c3e762ab214a"}],"role":"originator"},{"party":[{"contactId":"340c966f-895b-4bbc-88f3-f18e2771b361"}],"role":"originator"},{"party":[{"contactId":"e92f0af0-de70-4ad0-8f7f-40e11322535c"}],"role":"originator"}],"date":[{"date":"1989-01-01T09:00:00.000Z","dateType":"publication"}],"onlineResource":[{"uri":"https://doi.org/10.1017/S0007485300051361"}],"identifier":[{"identifier":"10.1017/S0007485300051361","namespace":"info:doi/"},{"identifier":"0-03-025397-7","namespace":"urn:isbn"}],"title":"An captured in the emergent insect traps."},{"sourceId":"0d96984d-5d88-4c5f-96d4-9075342548f3","sourceCitation":{"responsibleParty":[{"party":[{"contactId":"33ee59ca-539e-4eb4-ad68-787016a76f86"}],"role":"publisher"},{"party":[{"contactId":"4ffae1dd-4e9c-4efe-bc99-706f7df99086"}],"role":"originator"},{"party":[{"contactId":"67919dee-021c-48c3-af2d-dddd640a0223"}],"role":"originator"},{"party":[{"contactId":"486424ff-1e5c-4013-9488-6d286f3aacf6"}],"role":"originator"}],"date":[{"date":"2008-01-01T09:00:00.000Z","dateType":"publication"}],"identifier":[{"identifier":"978-0757563218","namespace":"urn:isbn"}],"title":"An Introduction to the Aquatic Insects of North America (4th ed.)"},"scope":{"scopeCode":"fieldSession"},"description":"The standard reference on the taxonomy, biology and ecology of aquatic insects with updated keys to separate life stages of all major taxonomic groupings"}],"statement":"In each study pond (n = 12), deployed one floating emergence trap in the approximate center of the pond and tethered the trap in place using rebar anchors (Cushman, 1983). At a sub-sample of ponds (n = 8), a second emergence trap was placed in the pond margin, in the transition zone between wetted and dry habitats. Each trap was fitted with a removable petri dish (14 cm diameter) coated with Tree Tanglefoot (Tanglefoot Company, Grand Rapids, Michigan), a sticky substance that captured emerging adults. Samples were collected every 14 days in 2012 and every 10 days in 2013; replacing each petri dish and storing samples as soon as possible in a cool dark location for later processing. Traps were deployed on 29 June 2012 and 10 June 2013. Final collections were made on 11 August in 2012 and 1 August in 2013"}],"resourceDistribution":[{"distributor":[{"contact":{"role":"publisher","party":[{"contactId":"1b759b80-bb2a-4b66-898d-56e4c9b4a341"}]},"orderProcess":[{"fees":"None"}],"transferOption":[{"onlineOption":[{"uri":"https://doi.org/10.5066/P9FG9DEO","protocol":"HTTPS","description":"Land webpage"}],"distributionFormat":[{"formatSpecification":{"title":"CSV","edition":"Unknown"},"compressionMethod":"7Zip-Compression applied by the 7-Zip utility using default compression (5). The taxonomic ranking above Infraclass can be found in the accompanying table, emergeInsects_slopePonds_insectData_NorthSlopeAK_Laske_2012_2013.csv.","entityReference":[{"title":"Author defined"}]}],"dictionaryIncludedWithResource":true,"locale":[{"language":"eng","country":"USA","characterSet":"UTF-8"}],"domain":[{"domainId":"3d09ac21-0b77-4566-9188-69a53f9d3cb6","codeName":"pond_class","commonName":"Pond Class","description":"A concatenation of several data attributes.

CN = Chipp North, name of study site

pond class -- the type of pond, KL - large coalescent pond, KS - small coalescent pond, P - low centered polygon pond, and TR - trough pond

treatment_pond_number -- the other portion of the study used various fertilizer treatments. Only control ponds were used. 1-3 are replicates of the pond class. One pond CONTROL3Re was picked up in 2013 when a new pond was needed, "Re", is the replacement."},{"domainId":"4a7e70b2-0596-4293-b61f-263796fdd7bb","codeName":"basin_id","description":"BasinID is a combination of site attributes: year - location - pond_class - treatment_pond_number - zone - cycle. 

location -- CN stand for Chipp North, the name of the study site; pond class -- the type of pond; KL - large coalescent pond, KS - small coalescent pond; P - low centered polygon pond; and TR - trough pond

treatment_pond_number -- the other portion of the study used various fertilizer treatments, used only the control ponds here. 1-3 are replicates of the pond class. One pond CONTROL3Re was picked up in 2013 when a new pond was needed, "Re", is the replacement.","commonName":"Basin Id"},{"domainId":"91c38f14-9fea-4282-8aca-1feaa023a936","domainItem":[{"reference":{"title":"Author defined"},"name":"C","value":"Center of pond","definition":"Center of pond"},{"name":"M","value":"Margin of pond","definition":"Margin of pond","reference":{"title":"Author defined"}}],"domainReference":{"title":"Author defined"},"codeName":"zone","description":"Domain for location of emergent insect trap deployment in a pond","commonName":"Zone"},{"domainId":"f59ab45d-370a-4913-9f3d-e8d40a85954c","domainItem":[{"name":"thermokarst_l","value":"Large thermokarst pond","definition":"Large thermokarst pond","reference":{"title":"Koch et al., 2014"}},{"name":"thermokarst_s","value":"Small thermokarst pond","definition":"Small thermokarst pond","reference":{"title":"Koch et al., 2014"}},{"name":"polygon","value":"Polygon pond","definition":"Polygon pond","reference":{"title":"Koch et al., 2014"}},{"name":"trough","value":"Trough pond","definition":"Trough pond","reference":{"title":"Koch et al., 2014"}}],"domainReference":{"title":"Koch, J.C., Gurney, K. and Wipfli, M.S., 2014, Morphology-dependent water budgets and nutrient fluxes in Arctic thaw ponds: Permafrost and Periglacial Processes, 25(2), pp. 79-93; doi.org/10.1002/ppp.1804"},"codeName":"class","description":"Type of pond","commonName":"Class"},{"domainId":"8c8f4447-f80c-4564-ad97-ebd70c90ef28","domainReference":{"title":"Author defined"},"codeName":"NULL","commonName":"Null","description":"Empty of data, signifying no data was captured or is applicable"},{"domainId":"8cb2cafc-7071-4dd2-a3db-be675af543c2","domainReference":{"title":"Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS)"},"codeName":"infraclass","description":"The principal taxonomic category that ranks animals (insects) above Superorder and below Subclass. There are two possible Infraclasses of insects within this study.","commonName":"Infraclass"},{"domainId":"392ba288-cd5b-4327-9082-aa678907d87c","domainReference":{"title":"Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS)"},"codeName":"super_order","commonName":"Superorder","description":"The principal taxonomic category that ranks animals (Insects) above Order and below Infraclass. There are three possible values for Superorders of insects within this study."},{"domainId":"717c6b1e-2b5f-42a1-b3a1-7832a68971ff","domainReference":{"title":"Integrated Taxonomic Information System (ITIS)"},"codeName":"order","commonName":"Order","description":"The principal taxonomic category that ranks animals above Suborder and below Superorder. There are six possible values for Order of insects within this study."},{"domainId":"663ee651-2c98-4f42-9729-67576451d14d","domainReference":{"title":"Integrated Taxonomic Information System"},"codeName":"sub_order","commonName":"Suborder","description":"The principal taxonomic category that ranks animals above Infraorder and below Order. There are nine possible values for Suborder of insects within this study."},{"domainId":"f61a4996-d6c0-4d80-8fff-a1fc17258770","domainReference":{"title":"Integrated Taxonomic Information System"},"codeName":"infra_order","commonName":"Infraorder","description":"The principal taxonomic category that ranks animals above Superfamily and below Suborder. There are nine possible values for the Infraorder of insects within this study."},{"domainId":"b9158d3d-2244-4fe3-9b4b-773de7c8b0ee","domainReference":{"title":"Integrated Taxonomic Information System"},"codeName":"super_family","commonName":"Superfamily","description":"The principal taxonomic category that ranks animals above Family and below Infraorder. There are six possible values for Suborder of insects within this study."},{"domainId":"a35ad211-8245-4e2f-b3fa-9b8bc59338a1","domainReference":{"title":"Integrated Taxonomic Information System"},"codeName":"family","commonName":"Family","description":"The principal taxonomic category that splits up the categorical ranking of animal (insects) detail characters below Superfamily. There are 25 possible values for Families of insects within this study. The Family of insect is the most highly defined and terminal taxonomic rank herein. Family is the rank immediately above both Genus and Species."},{"domainId":"353aa95b-7e5a-4489-b35d-34603edeb9d4","domainReference":{"title":"Author defined"},"codeName":"sampleId","description":"Pond sample identifier at the time of collection","commonName":"Sample Id"},{"domainId":"21ec8a05-681f-48e0-bf96-29cdbe861e38","domainReference":{"title":"Author defined"},"codeName":"taxon","commonName":"Taxon","description":"Alphabetic code representing the four first characters of the taxon, followed by an underscore and then followed by the characters representing the life cycle stage for each insect captured. For example, BAET_adult, lists the first four uppercase characters that represent the taxon of the sample, followed by the life cycle stage of the insect, in this case an adult."},{"domainId":"22663b81-2e91-4ca2-b31d-59f32f7ee8dc","codeName":"site","commonName":"Site","description":"A concatenation of several data attributes."}]}}
